FactTweet: Before it was a Latino neighborhood, Pilsen was mostly composed of immigrants of central European descent.
FactText: Before it was a Latino neighborhood, Pilsen was mostly composed of immigrants of central European descent.

FactTweet: Mexican-Americans moved to Chicago's Pilsen neighborhood after  being displaced by the Eisenhower Expressway.
FactText: Latino roots in Chicago's Pilsen neighborhood started in the 1950s, when many Mexican-Americans moved to the area after being displaced by construction of The Eisenhower Expressway.

FactTweet: Today, Pilsen is considered a Latino neighborhood, but it didn't become that way until the 60s.
FactText: Chicago's Pilsen neighborhood is home to many Latinos, but it didn't become that way until the '60s.

FactTweet: Today, Little Village is considered a Latino neighborhood, but it didn't become that way until the 70s.
FactText: Chicago's Little Village is considered a Latino neighborhood today, but it didn't become that way until the '70s.

FactTweet: During the Cold War, the U.S. Army built anti-aircraft missile sites along the shores of Lake Michigan.
FactText: During the Cold War, the U.S. Army built anti-aircraft missile sites along Lake Michigan at: Belmont Harbor, Burnham Park, and Jackson Park in Chicago.

FactTweet: Due to Lake Michigan's weak radar, many people feared Russian bombers would attack Chicago during the Cold War.
FactText: During the Cold War, radar over Lake Michigan was weak, and many feared Russian bombers could attack the Chicago area undetected.

FactTweet: During the Cold War, Chicago was protected by anti-aircraft missiles. Some of the missiles were nuclear-tipped.
FactText: During the Cold War, Chicago stationed anti-aircraft missiles to destroy enemy bombers. Some sported nuclear-tipped warheads.

FactTweet: In the mid-1950s, the U.S. military spread 600 Nike Ajax anti-aircraft missiles across the Chicago area.
FactText: In the mid-1950s, the U.S. military spread 600 Nike Ajax anti-aircraft missiles across the Chicago area.

FactTweet: During the Cold War, Chicago had 22 anti-aircraft sites to defend against air strikes.
FactText: During the Cold War, the Chicago area housed 22 anti-aircraft sites to defend against enemy air strikes.

FactTweet: Anarchism did not have a violent reputation until the Haymarket bombing gave it a bad name.
FactText: Before Chicago's Haymarket Bombing of 1886, the anarchist movement did not have a reputation of violence.

FactTweet: Protestors present at Chicago's Haymarket bombing of 1886 were laborers calling for an 8-hour workday.
FactText: Protestors present at Chicago's Haymarket bombing of 1886 were laborers calling for an 8-hour workday.

FactTweet: Chicago's Haymarket bombing occurred during the first-ever national general strike in 1886.
FactText: Chicago's Haymarket bombing occurred during the first-ever national general strike in 1886.

FactTweet: After the Haymarket bombing Chicago put 8 anarchists on trial, but only a few were present at the crime scene.
FactText: Eight labor radicals were found guilty in charges related to Chicago's Haymarket bombing of 1883. Most of them had not been present at the scene.

FactTweet: The eastern pipistrille is the smallest bat species in Chicago, weighing only as much as a penny.
FactText: The eastern pipistrille is the smallest bat species in Chicago. It weighs only as much as a penny.

FactTweet: Golf courses are a favorite hangout spot of certain Chicago-area bat species.
FactText: Golf courses are a favorite hangout spot of certain Chicago-area bat species.

FactTweet: At least seven species of bats live within Chicago's city limits.
FactText: At least seven species of bats live within Chicago's city limits.

FactTweet: The Chicago alley behind the 1903 Iroquois Theater fire was nicknamed The Alley of Death and Mutilation.
FactText: After a tragic fire, the alley behind the former Iroquois Theater was nicknamed The Alley of Death And Mutilation, per a 1903 Chicago Tribune article.

FactTweet: Approximately 600 died during the first fifteen minutes of Chicago's infamous Iroquois Theater fire of 1903.
FactText: Approximately 600 died during the first fifteen minutes of Chicago's infamous Iroquois Theater fire of 1903.

FactTweet: More people died during the Iroquois Theater fire of 1903 than died during the Great Chicago Fire of 1873.
FactText: More people died during the Iroquois Theater fire of 1903 than died during the Great Chicago Fire of 1873.

FactTweet: Chicago's 1903 Iroquois Theater fire was the deadliest single-building fire in the U.S. until Sept. 11, 2001.
FactText: Chicago's 1903 Iroquois Theater fire was the deadliest single-building fire in the U.S. until Sept. 11, 2001.

FactTweet: The most common feature of the Chicago accent is the raised "A" vowel which turns "Hat" into "H-ea-t"
FactText: The most common feature of the Chicago accent is the raised "A" vowel which turns "Hat" into "H-ea-t"

FactTweet: Elements of the famous Chicago accent remain the same from neighborhood to neighborhood.
FactText: Elements of the famous Chicago accent remain the same from neighborhood to neighborhood.

FactTweet: A water pump at a Cook County Forest Preserve attracts crowds for it's supposedly mythical, superior water.
FactText: A water pump at a Cook County Forest Preserve attracts crowds for it's supposedly mythical, superior water.

FactTweet: A water pump at a Cook County Forest Preserve serves as a rare source of spring water in the Chicago area.
FactText: A water pump at a Cook County Forest Preserve serves as a rare source of spring water in the Chicago area.

FactTweet: Many people believe the water from a specific pump at a Cook County forest preserve has "medicinal" qualities.
FactText: Many people believe the water from a specific pump at a Cook County Forest Preserve  has "medicinal" qualities. Test suggest it's just typical well water.

FactTweet: California Ave. was named in light of Chicago Czechs who sought to buy homes in the city's "western paradise."
FactText: Chicago's California Avenue got its name because it was considered a "western paradise" for upwardly-mobile immigrants of Czech heritage.

Readable Slug: Two flats and the Pilsen neighborhood
FactTweet: Chicago's Pilsen neighborhood was named for the town Plzeň in the Bohemian region of the Czech Republic.
FactText: Chicago's Pilsen neighborhood was named for the town Plzeň in the Bohemian region of the Czech Republic.

Readable Slug: Two flats and the Czech population
FactTweet: Many of Chicago's two-flat homes were built by Bohemian (Czech) immigrants at the turn of the 20th century.
FactText: Many of Chicago's two-flat homes were built by Bohemian (Czech) immigrants at the turn of the 20th century.

FactTweet: In 1989 a Civil War vet's remains were recovered from a Chicago construction site. The body was mostly intact.
FactText: In 1989 a Civil War veteran's remains were recovered from a Chicago construction site. Having been embalmed with arsenic, the body was mostly intact.

FactTweet: In 1989 a construction project uncovered remnants of a vast potters field near the former Dunning Asylum.
FactText: A 1989 construction project uncovered remnants of a potter's field near Chicago's former Dunning Asylum. An assessment suggested that 15,000 - 38,000 people had once been buried nearby.

FactTweet: Notorious serial killer, bigamist Johann Hoch was buried at Chicago's Dunning Asylum in 1906.
FactText: Notorious serial killer and bigamist Johann Hoch was buried at Chicago's Dunning Asylum for the Insane in 1906.

FactTweet: Notorious Chicago-area serial killer Johann Hoch had married 30 women and killed at least 10 of them.
FactText: Notorious Chicago-area serial killer Johann Hoch had married 30 women and killed at least 10 of them.

Readable Slug: Dunning as tomb for the living
FactTweet: In 1889, a judge described Cook County's Dunning Asylum for the Insane as a "tomb for the living."
FactText: In 1889, a judge described Cook County's Dunning Asylum for the Insane as a "tomb for the living."

FactTweet: Fact finding isn't cheap. Please donate and keep the facts going!
FactText: Fact-finding isn't cheap, and we're funded by folks like you. Curious City is non-profit, and we hope you find us worthy of donating a few bucks to keep stuff like this going. Thanks!

FactTweet: There are at least six sets of tunnels beneath portions of Chicago's Loop.
FactText: There are at least six sets of tunnels beneath portions of Chicago's Loop.

FactTweet: There are approximately 60 miles of nearly-forgotten freight tunnels beneath Chicago's Loop.
FactText: There are approximately 60 miles of nearly-forgotten freight tunnels beneath Chicago's Loop.

FactTweet: Nearly-forgotten freight tunnels beneath Chicago's Loop were first intended to string up telephone lines.
FactText: Nearly-forgotten freight tunnels beneath Chicago's Loop were first intended to string up telephone lines.

FactTweet: In 1992 construction crews punctured a forgotten underground tunnel, causing a massive flood in Chicago's Loop.
FactText: In 1992 construction crews punctured a forgotten underground tunnel, causing a massive flood in Chicago's Loop.

FactTweet: Between 1882 and 1906, the street car (not the "L" train) was Chicago's main mode of public transit.
FactText: Between 1882 and 1906, the street car (not the "L" train) was Chicago's main mode of public transit.

FactTweet: Chicago’s coldest recorded wind chill ever was -82 degrees. It came on Christmas Eve, 1983.
FactText: Chicago’s coldest recorded wind chill ever was -82 degrees. It came on Christmas Eve, 1983.

FactTweet: In the winter of 1978-1979, Chicago went 107 continuous days with snow on the ground.
FactText: In the winter of 1978-1979, Chicago went 107 continuous days with snow on the ground.

FactTweet: Chicago's worst snowstorm started on January 26, 1967. It dumped 23 inches of snow.
FactText: Chicago's worst snowstorm started on January 26, 1967. It dumped 23 inches of snow over a span of nearly 29 hours.

FactTweet: When Chicago was first made a settlement, it sat upon a very peat-rich, swampy soil.
FactText: When Chicago was first made a settlement, it sat upon a very peat-rich, swampy soil.

FactTweet: In 1856 Chicago lifted itself up to 14 feet off the ground to keep from sinking into marshland.
FactText: In 1856, Chicago lifted streets and many buildings up to 14 feet off the ground to keep from sinking into the mosquito-infested marshland.

FactTweet: 19th century newspapers wrote that skyscrapers would be a poor fit for Chicago's soft "jelly-cake"-like ground.
FactText: 19th century newspapers wrote that skyscrapers were a poor fit for Chicago's soft ground, which they described as “a great jelly-cake.”

FactTweet: Chicago's Auditorium Building, built in 1889, sunk enough that it needed four new steps to meet the street.
FactText: Chicago's Auditorium Building and Theater, built in 1889, sunk enough to require four steps between the street and its entrance.

FactTweet: Chicago anchored a skyscraper in dolomite bedrock in 1957, decades after they'd been "floated" on marshy soil.
FactText: Chicago built its first skyscraper anchored in dolomite in 1957, almost 70 years after skyscrapers were first "floated" on the city's marshy soil.

FactTweet: Chicago often builds skyscrapers on hardpan soil, above solid bedrock.
FactText: Chicago often builds skyscrapers on hardpan soil, above solid bedrock.

FactTweet: After the Great Fire of 1871, Chicago became an industry hub for fire-proof terra cotta tile.
FactText: After the Great Fire of 1871, Chicago became an industry hub for fire-proof terra cotta tile.

FactTweet: Chicago's Uptown neighborhood once house enough Southern migrant workers to be nicknamed "Hillbilly Heaven."
FactText: Chicago's Uptown neighborhood once house enough Southern migrant workers to be nicknamed "Hillbilly Heaven."

FactTweet: Uptown's Southerners were stereotyped in 50s-era articles such as "Girl Reporter Visits Jungles of Hillbillies."
FactText: Southern migrants in Chicago's Uptown neighborhood were the target of stereotypes in '50s-era articles such as "Girl Reporter Visits Jungles of Hillbillies."

FactTweet: During WWII, the Chicago area was home to several German prisoner of war camps.
FactText: During WWII, the Chicago area was home to several German prisoner of war camps.

FactTweet: The Chicago-area's largest WWII POW camp was at Fort Sheridan, with 1,300 POWs housed there from 1944 to 1945.
FactText: The largest WWII POW camp in the Chicago area was at Fort Sheridan, with 1,300 POWs housed there from 1944 to 1945.

FactTweet: During WWII, German POWs were held at a camp in the Sweet Woods Forest Preserve near Thornton, Illinois.
FactText: During WWII, several hundred German POWs were held at a camp in the Sweet Woods Forest Preserve near Thornton, Illinois.

FactTweet: After WWII, a facility built for German POWs was demolished. It became a Girl Scout camp in the '60s.
FactText: After WWII, a facility built for German POWs was demolished. It became a Girl Scout camp in the '60s.

FactTweet: Some German WWII POWs imprisoned in Des Plaines, Illinois, were allowed at flower shop nearby.
FactText: Some German WWII POWs imprisoned in Des Plaines, Illinois, were allowed at flower shop nearby.

FactTweet: Reinhold Pabel, a German WWII POW, escaped and hid for years in Chicago's Uptown neighborhood.
FactText: Reinhold Pabel, a German WWII POW, escaped from his camp in Rockford, Illinois. For years, he hid in Chicago's Uptown neighborhood -- even opening a bookstore there.

FactTweet: Camp Skokie, a facility that housed German WWII prisoners, was located near Glenview, Illinois.
FactText: Camp Skokie, a facility that housed German WWII prisoners, was located near Glenview, Illinois.

FactTweet: During WWII, German POWs were held in Arlington Fields Naval Air base, near Arlington Heights, Illinois.
FactText: During WWII, German POWs were held in Arlington Fields Naval Air base, near Arlington Heights, Illinois.
